questions.text: Like other fat-soluble vitamins, Vitamin A can be stored in the body and cause toxicity. Vitamin A toxicity leads to which of the following conditions? Bronze Diabetes Alopecia Loss of appetite Ecchymotic patches Increased intracranial tension Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2,5 Excess of vitamin A is toxic and manifests as: Raised Intracranial tension resembling Brain Tumour (Known as Pseudo Tumour Cerebri) Hepatomegaly Liver damage Hyperlipidemia Blurred Vision Alopecia Dry pruritic skin Ecchymotic patches appear due to Vitamin K deficiency Bronze Diabetes occurs as a result of iron overload. Loss of appetite generally occurs as a result of vitamin D toxicity.

questions.text: A teenager is presented with severe cystic acne. The patient is prescribed Isotretinoin. Chemically isotretinoin is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

13 cis-retinoic acid Isotretinoin is a synthetic retinoid, i.e. , 13 cis retinoic acid uses: Acne vulgaris Oral leukoplakia Pityriasis rubra pilaris Side effects: Alopecia Tendon rupture/tendinitis Elevation of Lipoprotein (a) Teratogenicity Extra Information: All-trans retinoic acid is involved in cell differentiation. All-trans retinoic acid binds to nuclear receptors (retinoic acid receptors). The activated retinoic acid-receptor complex interacts with response elements on the DNA and regulates the transcription of specific genes in different tissues. Ex: Control of expression of keratin gene in epithelial tissues. NOTE: All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) treats acute promyelocytic leukemia.

questions.text: A child of age six years was brought to the pediatric department. A patient complained of pain in the legs past six months. Upon examination, a bowing deformity was reported in the patient's lower extremities. The X-ray investigation of the legs revealed bowing of tibiae and widening of epiphyses. Bone mineral density was normal. Deficiency of which vitamin is responsible for the above manifestations?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin D Vitamin D is essential for the mineralization of bones. Its deficiency results in bone deformities in children called rickets.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: B Vitamin B1 deficiency results in Beri Beri Option: C Vitamin C deficiency manifests as scurvy and repeated infections Option: D Vitamin A deficiency manifests as night blindness, Bitot's spots, and keratomalacia.

questions.text: Vitamin K is the only fat-soluble vitamin with coenzyme function and has three forms. Which of the following is the synthetic water-soluble vitamer of vitamin K?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Menadione Vitamers are different forms of vitamins. Vitamin K has three different vitamers: Figure: Vitamin K1 -Plant source - animal source, - synthesized by the bacterial flora present in the intestine, - stored in the liver. Figure: Vitamin K3 - a water-soluble, synthetic form - can be converted into k2 in the liver

questions.text: A newborn baby of 7 days of age was taken to the hospital's emergency ward. The baby was bleeding. After examination, the prothrombin time was reduced to below 50% of the normal value. No other abnormality was detected. Select the correct statement that describes the condition.

options.label: B
options.text: Newborn infant with low levels of vitamin K

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Newborn babies suffer from a deficiency of vitamin K. It can be early onset within 24 h of birth infants, Classic bleeding within the first week after birth, and Late-onset bleeding within six months after childbirth.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. Oral administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics for a prolonged period can alter the colonic microbes and result in the deficiency of vitamin K2 that is produced by colonic microns mainly. Option: B. Newborn infants have low levels of vitamin K. It is essential for the post-translational modification of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. Deficiency of vitamin K results in bleeding in newborn It can be corrected by intravenous administration of vitamin K. Option: C. If the mother of a newborn baby takes anticoagulants, these induce bleeding in the infant baby via breastfeeding.

questions.text: Vitamin E family consists of tocopherols and tocotrienols with four vitamers α, β, γ, and δ in each group. They have powerful biological antioxidant activity, which differs among these forms. Which of the following tocopherol is the most active form of vitamin E?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alpha α-tocopherol is the most active form . It is also a form of vitamin E preferentially absorbed and accumulated in humans. Look at the isoprene side chain of tocopherol. All fat-soluble vitamins contain isoprene units. Structure of alpha-tocopherol .

questions.text: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiencies are generally associated with microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Why does vitamin B6 deficiency result in small (microcytic), pale (hypochromic) RBCs?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ALA synthase is affected ALA synthase catalyzes the first and rate-limiting step of heme synthesis. PLP (Vitamin B6) is necessary for this reaction. That is why in B6 deficiency, the hemoglobin synthesis is low, resulting in small size and hypochromic RBCs leading to microcytic and hypochromic anemia.

questions.text: Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is synthesized from the vitamin pyridoxine (vitamin B6) and is a cofactor of various reactions. The reactive aldehyde group of PLP usually is a part of covalent catalysis for these enzyme-catalyzed reactions. PLP is required for the activity of all of the following enzymes except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase Vitamin B6 is involved in a variety of reactions, as shown below: Carbohydrate metabolism: Glycogen Phosphorylase Amino Acid Metabolism: All Transaminases – ALT, AST Cystathionine β-synthase, Cystathioninase, decarboxylases, Kynureninase, Heme synthesis, ALA synthase Lipid metabolism: Synthesis of arachidonic acid, Synthesis of Sphingosine (Serine palmitoyltransferase & sphingosine-1-phosphate lyase) Steroid Hormone Action: Removes hormone receptor complex from DNA & terminates the hormone's action . Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase requires NADP or vitamin B3 (Niacin) as a coenzyme.

questions.text: Dietary antioxidants (e.g., vitamins, carotenoids, flavonoids) and endogenously produced free-radical scavengers have a common structural feature, a conjugated double-bond system such as an aromatic ring. All of the following vitamins are antioxidants EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin K Remember the antioxidant vitamins by the mnemonic ACE or CEA . Note that it is the β carotene form of Vitamin A. β-carotene and vitamin E are lipid phase anti-oxidant . Vitamin C is an aqueous phase antioxidant. Extra Edge: Vitamin E is a chain-breaking antioxidant.

questions.text: Select the TRUE statement about vitamin B12:

options.label: A
options.text: Does not act as a cofactor

options.label: B
options.text: Involved in the transfer of amino groups

options.label: C
options.text: Requires a specific glycoprotein for its absorption

options.label: D
options.text: Dietary requirement is met by intake of plant products

questions.correct_answer: C. Requires a specific glycoprotein for its absorption
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Requires a specific glycoprotein for its absorption Option analysis: Methyl cobalamine and 5'-deoxy adenosyl cobalamine are the coenzyme forms of vitamin B12 → option a is excluded. Vitamin B6 is involved in the transfer of amino groups, not B12 → option b is excluded. Dietary source (milk, curd, cheese, egg, liver, meat, fish) of B12 is exclusive of animal origin, and no plant source of vitamin B12 → option d is excluded. Intrinsic factor (IF) , an intrinsic gastric factor (GIF), is a glycoprotein produced by the stomach's parietal cells. It is necessary to absorb B12 in the ileum →, so option c is the answer.

questions.text: A 20-month-old male infant presented with developmental delay, seizures, and eczema. His urine has a characteristic tom cat smell, and blood analysis indicated organic acidemia. The patient is advised to take biotin supplementation to treat which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multiple carboxylase deficiency Multiple carboxylase/biotinidase deficiency: Autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in H olocarboxylase synthase or biotinidase deficiency. These are required to generate the active form of biotin needed for carboxylation reactions (see Fig) Clinical features: Metabolic ketoacidosis Diffuse rash Alopecia Seizures Intellectual disability

questions.text: Many drugs are used as rescue therapy for preventing the adverse effects of anticancer drugs. One such drug, Folinic acid, is used during methotrexate therapy. Chemically, Folinic acid is which one of the following compounds?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5-formyl tetrahydrofolate Folinic acid is 5-formyltetrahydrofolate . It is also known as leucovorin and citrovorum factor. Folinic acid can be directly converted to N5, N10-methylene tetrahydrofolate .

Extraedge:

When methotrexate is used for chemotherapy, normal cells are also affected. Folinic acid is administered to rescue the normal cells from the toxic effect of methotrexate.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with progressive keratinization of the cornea?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin A Vitamin A deficiency is the most important preventable cause of blindness. The earliest sign of deficiency is a loss of sensitivity to green light → , followed by impairment to adapt to dim light →, then night blindness (inability to see in the dark) More prolonged deficiency leads to xerophthalmia: keratinization of the cornea and blindness .

questions.text: Wernicke encephalopathy is due to acute dietary deficiency of
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thiamine Wernicke’s (ophthalmoparesis, ataxia, and encephalopathy) and Korsakoff’s (retrograde and anterograde amnesia) syndrome is common in alcoholics due to thiamine deficiency. Pathogenesis: Thiamine is needed for oxidative decarboxylation reactions (pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase) that are very important for glucose metabolism. Thiamine deficiency produces a diffuse decrease in cerebral glucose utilization and results in mitochondrial damage . Glutamate accumulates due to impairment of α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase activity and, in combination with the energy deficiency, may result in excitotoxic cell damage.

questions.text: A patient with biliary atresia is more prone to a deficiency of
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vit K Biliary atresia leads to malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins This is an indirect question. Bile is needed for the digestion of lipids (micelle formation) Absence of bile leads to lipid malabsorption Lipid soluble vitamins are absorbed along with lipids Among the options, Vitamin K is the only fat-soluble vitamin. So, it is the answer. Moreover, the Absorption of carotenes and fat-soluble vitamins is impaired on a very low-fat diet.

questions.text: An overweight person goes on a high-carbohydrate and low-fat diet to lose body fat. To metabolize these excess carbohydrates, he has to increase the RDA level of which of the following vitamins?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thiamine Thiamine is needed for only four enzymes in the body. They are:- Pyruvate dehydrogenase α ketoglutarate dehydrogenase Transketolase Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase. Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase is involved in the metabolism of amino acids Rest all three enzymes are involved in carbohydrate metabolism. So, increased carbohydrate intake increases the requirement for thiamine also. Transketolase enzyme estimation is used in thiamine deficiency

questions.text: In Hyperhemolytic conditions or chronic hemolysis, hemoglobin is oxidatively degraded to release free heme from ferric hemoglobin. This free heme can accelerate tissue damage by promoting peroxidative reactions and activating inflammatory cascades. Which of the following protein binds to free heme to inhibit these effects?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hemopexin Option analysis: Ceruloplasmin: protein for transport of copper in blood Haptoglobin: protein produced by the liver that the body uses to clear free hemoglobin (found outside of red blood cells) from circulation Hemosiderin: is a Brown, golden pigment made of aggregates of several ferritins. It carries higher iron content but Releases iron more slowly than ferritin. Hemopexin: is a β1-globulin that binds free heme and inhibits its deleterious oxidative effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding anemia of chronic kidney disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Due to erythropoietin deficiency The anemia associated with CKD (chronic kidney disease) is: Normocytic : Size of RBCs is normal- no microcytic anemia (option 4)) Normochromic: concentration of hemoglobin is in the standard range, but the number of RBCs is decreased. This is due to decreased erythropoietin (option 2). Erythropoietin (EPO ) is a glycoprotein produced by the kidney and promotes the proliferation and differentiation of erythrocyte precursors in bone marrow (See fig). Chronic kidney disease → Renal failure → Low Erythropoietin → Low RBCs count The anemia in this condition is associated with: High ferritin ( intracellular iron-storage protein) presumably to keep iron stored in cells and away from pathogens (option 1). Low serum iron level due to low transferrin (iron-binding protein in plasma), hence total iron binding capacity (TIBC) is decreased in this condition

questions.text: Absence of which of the following enzyme in humans is responsible for the inability to synthesize ascorbic acid?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

L-Gulonolactone oxidase Uronic acid pathway is an alternate pathway for oxidation of glucose without ATP formation. An intermediate (L-gluconate) of this pathway can synthesize ascorbic acid in plants by the enzyme L-gluconolactone oxidase. However, ascorbic acid cannot be synthesized in human beings, other primates, guinea pigs, bats, and some birds and fishes because of the absence of L-Gulonolactone oxidase.

questions.text: Hypocalcemia occurs when calcium levels decrease to 6mg/dl (normal levels = 9-11mg/dl). It leads to seizures due to increased membrane excitability. All of the following are causes of hypocalcemia, EXCEPT
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin D intoxication Vitamin D intoxication leads to elevated plasma concentration of calcium This can lead to contraction of blood vessels, high blood pressure , and calcinosis —the calcification of soft tissues. Causes of hypercalcemia Causes of hypocalcemia ● Hyperparathyroidism ● Multiple myeloma and other osteolytic diseases ● Metastatic carcinoma of bone ● Thiazide diuretics ● Vitamin D intoxication ● Hypoparathyroidism ● Chronic Renal failure ● Malabsorption ● Acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A man has mild liver disease, arthritis, fatigue, and grayish skin pigmentation. Highly elevated level of iron is observed in his liver biopsy report. Which of the following conditions will be most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High Serum Ferritin The diagnosis is hemochromatosis. It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to a mutation in histocompatibility region of chromosome 6. In this disease, Iron absorption is increased from the small intestine resulting in increased serum iron and iron-ferritin complex (see Fig). As transferrin carries iron in the blood, higher transferrin saturation will be observed.

questions.text: A woman develops anemia in 6th month of her first pregnancy. Blood work revealed hypersegmented neutrophils with increased mean cell volume (MVC), morphological alterations in other cell types, and elevated serum levels of homocysteine. Anemia in this woman is caused most likely due to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Folate deficiency The most likely reason of this woman condition is folate deficiency. DNA synthesis indirectly requires Folic acid (folate required for conversion of dUMP to dTMP, leading to decreased thymidine, which is required for DNA synthesis). In Folic acid deficiency, DNA replication and, thus, cell division are affected. The cytoplasm of folate deficient cells grows at a normal rate, but cell division is delayed. So abnormally large cells are formed. This leads to megaloblastic anemia. As Folate is required for homocysteine to methionine conversion, its deficiency will cause homocysteine accumulation in serum. All Rapidly dividing cells, e.g. bone marrow and intestinal mucosa, are most affected. Supplements of Folate given in appropriate doses before conception can significantly reduce the incidence of Spina Bifida and other neural tube defects. Option b. Iron deficiency presents as microcytic, hypochromic anemia and would not elevate homocysteine.

questions.text: Iron in intestinal mucosal cells or stored in the liver may be transferred into the blood for transport to other tissues by some proteins. Which of the following molecules delivers iron to tissues by binding to specific cell surface receptors?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transferrin Transferrin is a β1-globulin synthesized in the liver and is the transporter of iron. Absorption and Transport of Iron Absorption in the intestinal cell: Cytochrome b reductase one or Duodenal cytochrome b (Dcytb ) is a ferric reductase enzyme that converts Fe 3+ to Fe 2+ , and aids the entry of Fe 2+ into the mucosal cell The ferrous iron is then transported in the cell by a divalent metal transporter (DMT-1). Divalent Metal/Cation Transporter 1(DMT1 or DCT1) is Located on the apical membrane of enterocytes. Body iron stores regulate DMT1 expression to maintain iron homeostasis. Transport in blood: For transport, ferrous iron needs to be oxidized to ferric iron. This is done by hephaestin , a membrane-associated ferroxidase protein . In the blood, ceruloplasmin, a copper-containing ferroxidase, oxidizes any ferrous iron to ferric iron Transferrin can carry two molecules of ferric ion. (apo transferrin + 2 Fe 3+ = Holo-transferrin) Transferrin delivers the iron to different tissue cells by receptor-mediated endocytosis. The iron can be incorporated into various iron-containing proteins or stored in ferritin.

Extraedge:

Iron storage form: Ferritin and Haemosiderin (Fe 3+ ). Regulate iron transport in circulation: Hepcidin (Fe 2+ ). The presence of carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT), which can be measured by isoelectric focusing (IEF), is used as a biomarker of chronic alcoholism.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented to OPD with hepatosplenomegaly and cirrhosis. Blood and urine examinations indicated a higher-than-normal level of free copper. The eye examination showed Kayser-Fleisher (KF) rings characteristic of Wilson's hepatolenticular degeneration. Which of the following gene is defective in this disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ATP 7A Defects in copper metabolism: Menkes disease Wilson's disease Defective gene & its product ATP7A- ATPase (chromosome) ATP7B (Chromosome 13) Inheritance ● X-linked recessive ● Autosomal recessive Pathogenic defect ● Intestinal absorption of copper ● Defective biliary excretion of copper ● Accumulation of copper in liver ● Spillage into circulation due to liver damage Blood and urinary copper ↓ ↑ Clinical features ● Kinky hair and those of copper deficiency ● Kayser-Fleischer ring in cornea ● Liver cirrhosis ● Neurological manifestations NOTE : Menkes is caused by defective lysyl oxidase enzyme, This results from a deficiency of its co-factor , i.e., copper due to a defect in the ATP7A gene.

questions.text: Which of the following mineral is a major component of biological membranes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phosphorus Lipid bilayer is made up of phospholipids- Lecithin, Sphingomyelin, Phosphatidyl Inositol, and Phosphatidyl serine. So, phosphorus is a major component of biological membranes.

questions.text: Vitamin E is the most widely distributed antioxidant in nature and protects cells from oxidative stress due to reactive oxygen species. Which of the following mineral has a similar action to vitamin E?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Selenium Selenium is needed for the enzyme glutathione peroxidase involved in the defense against free radical-mediated damage of lipid bilayer Vitamin E is also involved in the same So, selenium has a sparing effect on Vitamin E, i.e. Vitamin E deficiency can be corrected with selenium and vice versa.

questions.text: Uncontrolled phagocytosis of oxidized LDL particles is a major stimulus for developing foam cells and fatty streaks in the vascular subendothelium. This process may be inhibited by increased dietary intake of
questions.explanation:
Solution:

vitamin E Oxidation of lipid and protein portion of LDL is deleterious Oxidised LDL is taken up by scavenger receptors of the macrophages and leads to foam cell formation . This promotes atherosclerosis. Thus, it is important to prevent the oxidation of LDL. Vitamin E is the chain-breaking antioxidant that acts on the lipid phase of LDL and prevents lipid peroxidation. Other chain-breaking antioxidants are Vit A, C; SOD, and Uric acid Preventive antioxidants are glutathione peroxidase, and catalase

questions.text: Biotin, also called vitamin B7, is involved in a wide range of metabolic processes, primarily related to using fats, carbohydrates, and amino acids. Which of the following processes does not require this vitamin?

options.label: D
options.text: Propionyl CoA to Methyl Malonyl CoA

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glutamate to GABA Biotin (Vitamin B 7 ) is required mainly in carboxylation reactions Acetyl CoA to Malonyl CoA is done by enzyme Acetyl CoA carboxylase. Pyruvate to Oxaloacetate is done by the enzyme Pyruvate carboxylase . Propionyl CoA to Methyl Malonyl CoA is done by the enzyme Propionyl CoA carboxylase. Glutamate to GABA conversion is a simple decarboxylation reaction requiring vitamin B 6 , i.e., Pyridoxine.

Extraedge:

Biotin is a prosthetic group for all carboxylases . But few carboxylation reactions do not require Biotin . They are : CPS-I and II (Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase) CO 2 addition in C 6 of purines Pyruvate (3C) to Malate (4C) conversion by Malic enzyme Gamma Carboxylation of Glutamate (Vitamin K required, not Biotin)

questions.text: Histidine decarboxylase is an enzyme involved in the decarboxylation of histidine amino acid into a pharmacological amine, histamine. In humans, histamine is a significant biogenic amine. It is important as a neurotransmitter in controlling neurotransmission, gastric acid secretion, and immunity. Histidine decarboxylase is the sole enzyme in a single-step reaction. Name the vitamin whose derivative is covalently attached to histidine decarboxylase?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pyridoxine Histidine decarboxylase decarboxylates histidine via the coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate. It is the primary biological source of histamine. Histamine is a vital biogenic amine that moderates numerous physiologic processes.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: B. Forms of riboflavin as FMN and FAD serve as coenzymes in biochemical reactions Option: C. Thiamine as thiamine pyrophosphate serves as a coenzyme in metabolic reactions Option: D. Biotin serves as a coenzyme with carboxylase enzyme

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman was severely malnourished and developed macrocytic anemia. Her blood and urine analysis further revealed elevated levels of homocysteine and methylmalonate. The leucocyte transketolase levels were also below normal levels. What symptoms out of the following confirm that the anemia in this woman is due to a primary deficiency of cyanocobalamin (B12)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Elevated methylmalonate Macrocytic anemia: RBC's are more significant than their normal size Macrocytic anemia and elevated homocysteine, both can be caused by either B12 or folate deficiency. However, methyl malonyl CoA mutase specifically requires B12 and not folate for activity. MMA is elevated in 90–98% of patients with B 12 However, it is an acute condition but not a specific condition. The coenzyme form of B 12 , e., Adenosyl cobalamine, is required for the activity of methyl malonyl-CoA mutase, which covert methyl malonyl-CoA into succinyl-CoA (See figure). Due to deficiency of B12, methyl malonyl may accumulate, causing malonyl aciduria (See fig below).

Extraedge:

Normocytic anemia : Causes of normocytic anemia include acute blood loss, apoplastic anemia (bone marrow failure), and hemolytic anemia (abnormal breakdown of RBCs). Microcytic anemia : The majority of microcytic anemia is the result of insufficiency in haemoglobin synthesis or failure in hemoglobin synthesis, or both. E.g., iron deficiency. Dimorphic anemia : In Dimorphic Anemia, two distinct forms of red cell populations exist. It can occur when iron deficiency anemia responds to iron therapy after a normal blood transfusion to a patient with Hypochromic Anemia and Sideroblastic Anemia.

questions.text: Mark the true statement(s) regarding Vitamin K. All types of Vitamin K are fat soluble Acts as the Coenzyme for carboxylation of Glutamate Vitamin K3 is also known as Phylloquinone Vitamin K2 is synthesized from GI bacteria Warfarin is an anticoagulant for Vitamin K intoxication Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2,4,5 Menadione is the water-soluble form of vitamin K. Forms of vitamin K Vitamin K 1 Vitamin K 2 Vitamin K 3 another name Phylloquinone Menaquinone Menadione Source Several Green vegetables and prepared synthetically Synthesized by GI bacteria, supplies 50% human requirement Synthetic Analog of 1,4 naphthoquinone Solubility Fat soluble Fat soluble Diphosphate salt is water soluble

questions.text: Antioxidant defense enzymes, free-radical scavengers, cellular compartmentalization, metal sequestration, and repairing damaged cellular components counter oxygen toxicity in the form of reactive oxygen species. All of the following minerals can act as a natural-antioxidants except.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iron Zn plays a role as an anti-oxidant as it binds with the SH group of biomolecules protecting them from oxidation. Also, it increases the activation of anti-oxidant properties. Action of Se is complementary to Vitamin E, a constituent of Glutathione Peroxidase and Selenocysteine. Cu has a role as an anti-oxidant as it is present as a constituent in Cu/Zn SOD and Ceruloplasmin. Biological Functions of Iron: Transport and storage of O 2 (Hb and Mb) and CO 2 . In ETC as a component of cytochromes. Co-factor for many enzymes,g., Catalase, Peroxidase, Tryptophan Pyrrolase Role in phagocytosis (Peroxidase contains iron required for Phagocytosis).

questions.text: A patient presented in OPD with symptoms of Beri-Beri, such as psychosis, confabulations, progressive muscle wasting, etc., induced by Thiamine deficiency. The physician can trace the origin of his symptoms to all of the following conditions except

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic heart failure patient on diuretics

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Homocystinuria Homocystinuria (Option B) occurs due to deficiency of vitamins – B 6 , B 9 & B 12 (NOT Vitamin B 1 , i.e., Thiamine) .

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option C - Alcohol interferes with the absorption of Thiamine. Option A - Food faddism is generally used to describe a particular food or food group that is exaggerated in the routine diet or eliminated to cure one specific disease. A person believing this may exclude thiamin-containing food from their diet and consequently get thiamine deficiency. Option D - Loop diuretics cause thiamine deficiency by increasing urinary loss.

questions.text: Three different forms of vitamin D namely Cholecalciferol (D3), 1, 25 (OH)2 D3, and 25-OH D3, are produced as intermediates during the biosynthesis of vitamin D. The active form 1,25 (OH)2 Cholecalciferol or calcitriol is formed in which of following organs?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kidney Synthesis of Vitamin D: Activation of 7-dehydro cholesterol by UV light in the skin produces Cholecalciferol 25-hydroxylation in the liver to form 25-hydroxy cholecalciferol 1-alpha- hydroxylation in kidneys to form 1,25 dihydroxy cholecalciferol PTH activates 1-alpha hydroxylase of kidneys So, 25-hydroxy Cholecalciferol is formed in liver Whereas 1, 25 (OH)2 Cholecalciferol is formed in kidneys.

questions.text: Vitamins synthesized by human enzymes during metabolism are called as Atypical vitamins and do not include vitamins synthesized by intestinal microflora. Which of the following vitamin is synthesized by intestinal bacteria?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin K Vitamins that are synthesized by intestinal flora are Vitamin B 2 , B 5 , B 7 & Vitamin K. Vitamin B 3 and Vitamin D are two vitamins that are synthesized by the human body. So these are called Atypical Vitamins . These vitamins are synthesized by human enzymes during metabolism, not by intestinal bacterial enzymes. Vitamin B 3 is synthesized from Tryptophan Vitamin D is synthesized from 7-Dehydro Cholesterol by UV light in the skin.

questions.text: Vitamin E deficiency is rare in healthy people but can occur in patients with diseases related to poor fat digestion and absorption. Vitamin E deficiency can cause all of the following symptoms EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Megaloblastic anemia Deficiency of vitamin E can lead to: Neurological problems Difficulty coordinating movements (ataxia) Speech (dysarthria) Loss of reflexes in the legs (lower limb areflexia) Loss of sensation in the extremities (peripheral neuropathy). Ophthalmoplegia in susceptible persons.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option C : Megaloblastic anemia is caused by deficiency of vitamin B12 and folic acid

questions.text: Vitamins serve diverse biochemical functions such as antioxidants, growth and tissue differentiation, and hormonal and coenzymes for various metabolic enzymes. Which of the following vitamin perform its role by acting on intranuclear receptors?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin D Vitamin D is considered as a hormone as it is synthesized in the body, released in circulation. Its primary function is regulating calcium absorption and homeostasis; the action is mediated by binding to nuclear receptors to control gene expression of genes involved in calcium metabolism. In that way, the Mechanism of action of vitamin D resembles group II hormones, i.e., it binds with nuclear receptors.

questions.text: A patient is presented with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, which are getting worsened gradually. Blood examination revealed larger than normal RBCs. Which of the following is the best treatment which can be given to help alleviate these symptoms?
questions.correct_answer: C. Folic acid along with Hydroxycobalamin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Folic acid along with Hydroxycobalamin Vitamin deficiency Manifestation In folate megaloblastic anemia B 12 Megaloblastic anemia & neurological manifestations occur. Clinical manifestations of B 12 deficiency: Haematological : Megaloblastic anemia, Hypersegmentation of neutrophils. Neurological : Demyelination in peripheral nerves and spinal cord Megaloblastic anemia is due to a secondary deficiency of folate (folate trap in B 12 deficiency). Peripheral neuropathy is due to the accumulation of L-methyl malonic acid.

questions.text: Vitamin D is an atypical vitamin and can be synthesized in humans from its precursor cholesterol in the skin by exposure to UV light. Various intermediary forms of vitamin D are formed during its biosynthesis. Which of the following is the most potent form of vitamin D?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 25- dihydroxy cholecalciferol Vitamin D encompasses a group of sterols , which have a hormone-like function. Bioactive vitamin D, or calcitriol, is a steroid hormone that has long been known for its important role in regulating body levels of calcium and phosphorus and in the mineralization of bone. Forms of Vitamin D: Ergocalciferol (Vitamin D 2 ) → Formed from ergosterol and cholecalciferol (vitamin D 3 ) and are known as Pro-vitamins → Vitamins D2 and D 3 are not biologically active. 25-OH- cholecalciferol → Major storage and circulating form of vitamin D ● In clinical laboratory, we measure 25-(OH) cholecalciferol. 1, 25 dihydroxycholecalciferol → aka Calcitriol → most biologically active form of vitamin D Ergocalciferol (Vitamin D2) Formed from ergosterol and cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) and are known as Pro-vitamins Vitamins D2and D3 are not biologically active. 25-OH-cholecalciferol Major storage and circulating form of vitamin D In the clinical laboratory, we measure 25-(OH) cholecalciferol. 1, 25-dihydroxycholecalciferol aka Calcitriol a most biologically active form of vitamin D

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient was on Isoniazid therapy for tuberculosis. She developed rashes on the exposed parts of her body. She has disoriented memory. Family members give a history of diarrhea also. What is the diagnosis:

options.label: D
options.text: Some other drug has caused this

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Niacin deficiency Patient is showing Casal's Necklace and symptoms of Pellagra such D ermatitis, D ementia, D iarrhea Prolonged treatment with isoniazid leads to pyridoxine deficiency, which is required for endogenous synthesis of niacin so that the patient will develop pellagra. Etiology: Dietary deficiency of nicotinic acid or its precursor tryptophan . People with a staple diet of maize and Jowar. Maize is a poor source of nicotinic acid and tryptophan, and a part of nicotinic acid is in a bound form that is not assimilated in GIT. Jowar has a high content of leucine . The imbalance between leucine and other related amino acids interferes with the conversion of tryptophan to nicotinic acid. Malabsorption Drugs like INH, 5FU, and 6-mercaptopurine. Carcinoid syndrome T/t: Niacinamide 300-500 mg/day orally in divided doses.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male visited his dentist to consult about his loosening of teeth. A more detailed check-up reveals his gums are swollen, purple, and spongy. Physical examination revealed multiple splinter hemorrhages near the distal ends of the nail on the patient’s fingers, and wound healing is not proper in this patient. Is the patient showing deficiency symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin C Vitamin C acts as a cofactor for the enzyme lysyl and prolyl hydroxylase which is necessary for post-translation modification of collagen by hydroxylating the proline and lysine residue. These hydroxylated residues are necessary for hydrogen bonding between collagen chains, strengthening collagen fibers. Vitamin C deficiency leads to defective post-translational modification of collagen → loss of tensile strength of blood vessels leading to: Bleeding gums Ecchymoses Easy disability Poor wound healing (Features of scurvy).

questions.text: Assertion: FIGLU excretion test is done to determine the folic acid deficiency. Reason: FIGLU is the intermediate of histidine metabolism and needs tetrahydrofolic acid (THF).

options.label: A
options.text: Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a valid/correct statement. Still, the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.correct_answer: A. Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion Folate is required for converting FIGLU (Form Imino Glutamate) to Glutamate. FIGLU is accumulated in folic acid deficiency This is the basis of FIGLU excretion test (aka Histidine load test)

questions.text: Match the following plasma proteins with their functions: Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1e,2d,3f,4a Plasma protein Function I. Albumin Maintain oncotic pressure and transport of many compounds II. Prealbumin/ Transthyretin Transport thyroxine and retinol binding protein III. α 1 Globulins ● α 1 Anti – trypsin ● orosomucoid ● Thyroxine binding globulin. ● Transcortin Inhibitor of Serine protease Binds progesterone Major thyroid binding protein (TBG) Corticosteroid binding protein (CBG) IV. α 2 Globulins ● α 2 macroglobulin ● Ceruloplamin ● Haptoglobin ● Prothrombin Non-specific protease inhibitor Copper transport and ferroxidase activity Scavenger of free intravascular Hb clotting V. β. Globulins ● Hemopexin ● Transferrin ● Plasminogen Scavenger of Hb (this is used if haptoglobin is saturated) Iron transport Retraction of fibrin clot VI., ϒ- globulins Immunoglobulins (IgG type) VII. Fibrinogen Precursor of fibrin clot

questions.text: Match the following enzyme with the metal which acts as a- Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1c,2d,3f,4e All oxidases require copper, except two Cu Requiring Oxidase Not requiring Cu (Need Molybdenum ) ● Cytochrome C Oxidase ● Tyrosinase or Tyrosine Oxidase ● Ascorbic acid Oxidase ● Amino acid Oxidase ● Lysyl Oxidase ● Cytoplasmic SOD (Super Oxide Dismutase) ● Xanthine Oxidase ● Sulfite Oxidase ALA dehydratase is an enzyme of heme synthetic pathway. This enzyme contains zinc. Mitochondrial SOD requires Manganese. All kinases and Carboxylases require Magnesium. Exception: pyruvate Kinase requires potassium more than Magnesium.

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their defect: Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1e,2f,3b,4a Wilson disease: Due to excess of copper in the body causing hepatocellular degeneration Menke’s Disease: Due to deficiency of copper, also known as Menke's brittle and kinky hair syndrome Keshan's Disease: Endemic disease due to deficiency of Selenium affecting children and women of childbearing age Acrodermatitis Enteropathica: Disease due to deficiency of Zn affecting infants.

questions.text: The main biochemical function of riboflavin in the body is to act as a coenzyme for redox reactions. Riboflavin is a constituent of which of the following coenzyme?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

FMN Coenzymes of B-complex Vitamins Coenzyme (abbreviation) Derived from vitamin Atom or group transferred Dependent enzyme (example) Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) Thiamine Aldehyde or keto Transketolase Flavin mononucleotide (FMN) Riboflavin Hydrogen and electron L-Amino acid oxidase Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD+) Riboflavin Hydrogen and electron D-Amino acid oxidase Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) Niacin Hydrogen and electron Lactate dehydrogenase Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP+) Niacin Hydrogen and electron Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase Lipoic acid Lipoic acid Hydrogen and electron Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) Pyridoxine Amino or keto Alanine transaminase Coenzyme A (CoA) Pantothenic acid Acyl Thiokinase Tetrahydrofolate (FH 4 ) Folic acid One carbon (formyl, methenyl etc.) Formyl transferase Biocytin Biotin CO 2 Pyruvate carboxylase methylcobalamin; Deoxyadenosyl cobalamin Cobalamin methyl/isomerisation Methylmalonyl CoA mutase

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is presented with mental retardation, hypotonia, and growth retardation. Physical examination revealed depigmented grey and brittle kinky hair. Blood and urine examinations showed a lower Cu level than usual. Which of the following enzyme is affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lysyl oxidase The diagnosis is Menke’s Disease Menke Disease: XR disease due to Cu deficiency Deficient production of Cu binding P-type ATPase ATP7A in the intestine (Cu stays in intestinal cell, unable to enter blood) C/F ↓ Cu in blood and urine, ↓ cp (ceruloplasmin) Mental retardation, hypotonia, growth retardation, and premature birth Presents in infancy, death usually by three years As tyrosinase is affected which forms melanin so the patient has grey depigmented hair As lysyl oxidase affected, so defective collagen leads to brittle kinky hair

questions.text: As a plant-based food is limited in one or more amino acids, vegetarian diets generally combine various protein sources to supply all the essential amino acids. Limiting amino acid in maize is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tryptophan Maize protein Zein lacks tryptophan . As tryptophan is required for the synthesis of Niacin (60 mg of tryptophan is required to make 1 mg of niacin) Hence, in a high corn diet, the requirement of dietary niacin increases. Limiting Amino Acids (Some foods lacking particular amino acids) Maize lacks Tryptophan + Lysine Wheat lacks Threonine + Lysine Pulses lacks Methionine + Cysteine

questions.text: WHO recommends the administration of zinc along with new low-osmolarity oral rehydration solutions/salts (ORS) to treat diarrhea in children up to three months of age. The use of zinc in diarrhea is because it:

options.label: A
options.text: Reduces the risk, duration, and severity of diarrheal episodes

options.label: C
options.text: Regulates intestinal transport & absorption of water and electrolytes

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Zinc deficiency : Increased risk of gastrointestinal infections Adverse effects on the structure and function of the gastrointestinal tract Impaired immune function Disease is known as Acrodermatitis enteropathica Acrodermatitis enteropathica It is an autosomal recessive disease due to a defect in zinc absorbing transmembrane protein. Symptoms: Growth retardation Diarrhea Alopecia Dermatitis around the orifices Gonadal atrophy Impaired wound healing Zinc acts as a cofactor for: Carbonic anhydrase Carboxypeptidase Lactate dehydrogenase Alcohol dehydrogenase Alkaline phosphatase

questions.text: A patient presented in the OPD complaining of tingling sensations in their hand and feeling weak for the past few days. He was a vegetarian but did not eat a proper diet for some time. A thorough clinical examination showed the patient also had a red, softened tongue and roughed lips. The physician suspected a vitamin deficiency and ordered which of the following enzyme assay to detect this vitamin deficiency in this patient? Which of the following enzyme assay would you perform to detect the deficiency in the child?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glutathione reductase These are the typical presentation of riboflavin deficiency. The glutathione reductase activity test and marker enzyme for riboflavin deficiency, as this enzyme needs FAD as a prosthetic group. Symptoms of B2 deficiency: Corneal vascularization - earliest sign of deficiency. Glossitis – inflammation of the tongue (magenta tongue- characteristic), Cheilosis – redness and shiny appearance of lips. Angular stomatitis - lesions at the mucocutaneous junction at corners of the mouth, leading to painful fissures. Seborrhoeic dermatitis – rough, scaly skin because of desquamation.

questions.text: A 14-month-old infant is presented with dilated cardiomyopathy, hypothyroidism, inability to gain weight, and failure to thrive and is diagnosed with Keshan’s cardiomyopathy. Which of the following mineral supplements can help improve this child's condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Selenium Selenium as selenocysteine is an essential component of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase Selenium containing enzyme 5'-deiodinase converts thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine in the thyroid gland. Thioredoxin reductase , involved in purine nucleotide metabolism Sources- seafood and meat, nuts Deficiency – Keshan’s disease C/f: Endemic Cardiomyopathy (endemic to a province of China due to soil poor in Se) Muscular weakness and muscular dystrophy Inability to gain weight Hypothyroidism hypertension Eczema increased risk of stroke and even cancer Extra information: Toxicity – selenium toxicity lead to Selenosis . Clinical features are an emotional disturbance, diarrhea, hair loss, garlic odor (due to dimethyl selenide) in breath

questions.text: Iron is an important constituent of various biological molecules and can be stored in the body in the liver and intestinal cells. Various factors carefully regulate the iron reserves of the body. Which of the following vitamin increases the absorption of iron?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin C iron absorption – Increase iron absorption Decrease iron absorption ● Vitamin C ● Cysteine ● In iron deficiency anemia, iron absorption increase by 2-10 times ● Small peptides and amino acid ● Phytate (found in cereals) ● oxalate (found in leafy vegetable) ● diet with high phosphate content ● malabsorption syndromes such as steatorrhea ● In patients with partial or total surgical removal of stomach and/or intestine Vitamin C and Cysteine convert ferric iron to ferrous iron. Ferrous iron is soluble and easily absorbed.

questions.text: A patient undergoing warfarin therapy for thrombotic disorders will have decreased γ-carboxyglutamate residues on which of the following coagulation factors?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Factor II Vitamin K is the cofactor for γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues of the proteins to produce γ- carboxy glutamate . Clotting factors contain 4 to 6 γ-carboxyglutamate residues. The clotting factors 2,7, 9, and 10 are activated by vitamin K-assisted carboxylation as a part of the vitamin K cycle. Drug warfarin interferes with the recycling of vitamin K (see Fig). Hydroquinone form of Vitamin K activates a glutamate residue in the protein substrate to a carbanion, which reacts nonenzymatically with carbon dioxide to form γ-carboxyglutamate. Vitamin K epoxide is reduced to quinone by an epoxide reductase , and the quinone is reduced to the active hydroquinone by Vitamin K reductase. Dicumarol & warfarin inhibits the enzyme ( reductase ) that converts epoxide to active Vitamin K (hydroquinone). Hence all of the factors mentioned above will have decreased carboxy glutamate residues in patient taking warfarin.

questions.text: Vitamins of vitamin A are precursors for synthesizing the active forms of vitamin A and are found sufficiently in plant-based vegetarian diets. The most abundant form of dietary provitamin A is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beta carotene Carotenoids are provitamins of vitamin A which are present in plants. Most important carotenoid is beta carotene , which consists of two molecules of retinal joined end to end.

questions.text: A 20-year-old alcoholic malnourished patient presented to the hospital with respiratory distress. His pulse was 112 / minute. The patient had edema, hypertension, and systolic murmur along the left sternal edge. Bilateral crepitations were felt in the lungs. A diagnosis of congestive high-output cardiac failure was made. The physician suspected thiamine deficiency. Which of the following test will most likely support the diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Erythrocyte transketolase activity Chronic alcoholics are at risk for thiamine deficiency, This is a case of Wet/cardiacBeri-Beri, i.e., Vitamin B1deficiency. Vitamin B1 is mainly involved in Oxidative Decarboxylation reactions, so in B1deficiency, highly aerobic tissues, e.g., the heart and brain, fail first. Thiamine (vitamin B1) Deficiency It is assessed by Erythrocyte transketolase activity . Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is the marker for transketolase enzyme →which is involved in the HMP pathway (in RBCs) Activity of Transketolase is measured (not the quantity). No importance of checking serum thiamine Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) Deficiency RBC glutathione reductase is the marker for vitamin B2 deficiency.

questions.text: After consuming raw eggs, a person presents with weakness, fatigue & hypoglycemia. The doctor gave him vitamin tablets. Which enzyme deficiency is causing hypoglycemia in this patient:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pyruvate carboxylase Excess consumption of raw eggs, which contains a protein ‘avidin’→ tightly binds to Biotin (Vit B7) and is excreted along with biotin leading to biotin deficiency Biotin is required for all carboxylases . All carboxylases require ATP, also So, the enzyme affected is carboxylase which requires Biotin as a coenzyme When cooked, avidin is partially denatured, and its binding to biotin is reduced. So cooked egg whites are safe to consume. Pyruvate Carboxylase is the first enzyme of gluconeogenesis. Regarding other options: Glycogen Phosphorylase ROLE of Glycogenolysis Requires vitamin B6 (Pyridoxal phosphate) No relation with glycogen phosphorylase and egg avidin Glucose 6 phosphatase A common enzyme in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis Deficiency leads to hypoglycemia , and that is called Von Gierke’s disease (Type 1 glycogen storage disease). - Von Gierke’s disease is the most common glycogen storage disease, especially in children .

questions.text: A 15-month-old child is brought to a hospital for severe dialarhoea and dermatitis. She is also low in weight for her age. Physical examination shows the rash is not typical of yeast infection. It is distributed beyond the genital area and is prevalent on knees and tissue around the mouth and anus. She also has swelling of the hands and feet (edema) and has lost her hair. Which one of the following minerals supplements can most help relieve her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zinc The infant is suffering from Acrodermatitis enteropathica that is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by abnormalities in zinc absorption. It is characterized by simultaneous skin inflammation (Dermatitis) and Diarrhoea. The skin on cheeks, elbows, knees, and tissue around the mouth and anus is inflamed. Administration of zinc and new low-osmolarity oral rehydration solutions/salts (ORS) can reduce diarrheal episodes' risk, duration, and severity for up to three months. Minerals are essential for enzyme reactions (cofactors are distinguished from coenzymes that function in group transfer and undergo chemical reactions), including cobalt, copper, iron, molybdenum, selenium, and zinc. Examples include copper in cytochrome oxidase, iron in all the cytochromes, magnesium for all enzymes utilizing ATP, and zinc in lactate dehydrogenase. Arsenic, lead, and antimony cause disease when present in excess.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to his physician complaining of tenderness, aching of bone, and generalized muscle weakness. On consultation, it is evident that he has a very sedentary lifestyle, with most of his time spent watching television in his room. He also reports a poor diet, mostly devoid of fresh fruits and vegetables. A carpal spasm is noted after the cuff is inflated while taking the patient's blood pressure. Radiographs showed reduced bone density. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities would also be expected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Elevated parathyroid hormone This patient is most probably suffering from vitamin D deficiency and osteomalacia looking at the symptoms of his poor diet and indoor lifestyle. On the radiographic exam, osteomalacia can manifest with bone pain, muscle weakness, and reduced bone density. Vitamin D can be consumed from plants (ergocalciferol) or formed in sun-exposed skin (cholecalciferol). The active form of vitamin D is 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), produced in the kidney by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase (See vitamin D biosynthesis figure in text). Calcium homeostasis in the body is maintained by the interplay of calcitonin and parathyroid (PTH) hormones (refer to Fig).

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- This patient suffers from hypocalcemia, as indicated by reduced bone density. Vitamin D increases calcium reabsorption in the intestine and from both the distal convoluted tubule and collecting ducts of the kidney. So, Vitamin D deficiency will cause hypocalcemia (low serum calcium). 1a-Hydoxylase catalyzes the formation of 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), the active form of vitamin D. In response to hypocalcemia, the body increases parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion. PTH stimulates 1α-hydroxylase to maintain serum calcium. This patient has signs of hypocalcemia and would be expected to have increased activity of 1a-hydroxylase, not decreased. This patient has vitamin D deficiency and osteomalacia. As 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol is synthesized from ergocalciferol (vitamin D2), its levels would decrease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the physician because of lethargy, generalized weakness, and shortness of breath for several months. He is otherwise healthy and is not taking any medication. He looks pale on physical exam, and the capillary refill is delayed. Laboratory tests reveal a hematocrit of 25% and a mean corpuscular volume of 110 fL. What is the most likely cause of her abnormal laboratory findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pernicious anemia Pernicious anemia describes a disease in which the body cannot absorb vitamin B12. Vitamin B12 deficiency can result in megaloblastic anemia, characterized by increased mean corpuscular volume (macrocytosis), hyper-segmented neutrophils, and peripheral neuropathy. The presence of neurologic symptoms led to the term “pernicious anemia” because they are progressive and eventually irreversible. The absorption of vitamin B12 from the intestine requires a binding protein called intrinsic factor that is secreted by the gastric mucosa and absorbed in the ileum. A deficiency of the intrinsic factor causes pernicious anemia. Pernicious anemia can result from gastric atrophy at older ages or, more rarely, from mutations affecting the intrinsic factor itself that is present in childhood. I inability to absorb vitamin B12 from the gastrointestinal tract causes more severe deficiency than nutritional deprivation in vegetarian diets. The intrinsic factor may also be diminished by autoantibodies in autoimmune diseases such as diabetes mellitus or Grave’s disease (hyperthyroidism). Clinical signs of pernicious anemia may not appear until 3 to 5 years following the onset of vitamin B 12 deficiency, and the neurologic signs may occur without apparent anemia.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Pernicious anemia describes a disease in which the body cannot absorb vitamin B12. Vitamin B12 deficiency can result in megaloblastic anemia, characterized by increased mean corpuscular volume (macrocytosis), hyper-segmented neutrophils, and peripheral neuropathy. The presence of neurologic symptoms led to the term “pernicious anemia” because they are progressive and eventually irreversible. The absorption of vitamin B12 from the intestine requires a binding protein called intrinsic factor that is secreted by the gastric mucosa and absorbed in the ileum. A deficiency of the intrinsic factor causes pernicious anemia. Pernicious anemia can result from gastric atrophy at older ages or, more rarely, from mutations affecting the intrinsic factor itself that is present in childhood. I inability to absorb vitamin B12 from the gastrointestinal tract causes more severe deficiency than nutritional deprivation in vegetarian diets. The intrinsic factor may also be diminished by autoantibodies in autoimmune diseases such as diabetes mellitus or Grave’s disease (hyperthyroidism). Clinical signs of pernicious anemia may not appear until 3 to 5 years following the onset of vitamin B 12 deficiency, and the neurologic signs may occur without apparent anemia.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was hospitalized 30 days after his allogeneic stem cell transplant due to graft-versus-host disease and was immediately put on intravenous levofloxacin treatment. During an intravenous exchange, oozing of blood was noted from his venous access site. Laboratory examination of blood clotting tests reveals an average platelet count but prolonged prothrombin and partial thromboplastin time. A deficiency in the function of which of the following coagulation factors is the most likely cause of this patient's abnormal laboratory tests?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Factor II The long-term antibiotic treatment has caused vitamin K deficiency in this patient due to clearing of intestinal microflora, which is required for the synthesis of Vitamin K. Vitamin K is a necessary cofactor for hepatic production and activity of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, and proteins C and S. Factor II (prothrombin) deficiency would result in prolongation of prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B. Vitamin K is not required for factor V synthesis and would not be deficient in this patient. Option C and D. Mutations in the gene encoding factor VIII and factor XI are causes behind diseases hemophilia A and Hemophilia C (a rare coagulation disorder).

questions.text: A 56-year-old homeless man presents to ER with increased fatigability and exertional dyspnea. Physical examination shows significant lower extremity edema and decreased sensation over the ankles and feet. Further evaluation reveals cardiac dilation and increased cardiac output. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin B1 Thiamin Deficiency Affects the Nervous System & the Heart. Thiamin deficiency can result in three distinct syndromes: chronic peripheral neuritis, beriberi, which may or may not be associated with heart failure and edema; acute pernicious (fulminating) beriberi (shoshin beriberi), in which heart failure and metabolic abnormalities predominate, without peripheral neuritis; and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis, which is associated especially with alcohol and narcotic abuse. The role of thiamin diphosphate in pyruvate dehydrogenase means that in deficiency, there is an impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA. In subjects on a relatively high carbohydrate diet, this increases plasma concentrations of lactate and pyruvate, which may cause life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A: Vitamin A deficiency manifests as night blindness and hyperkeratosis of skin Option: C: Vitamin C deficiency manifests as scurvy Option: D: VitaminB12 deficiency results in pernicious anemia

questions.text: A Male patient in the age group 34 years came to the hospital. A Patient complained about numbness in hands and feet and a burning sensation. On examination, pallor was reported in the nail beds and conjunctiva. the patient gave a history the of taking the anti-tubercular drug, Isonicotinic acid hydrazide, for six months. Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deficiency of Vitamin B6 Given patient is showing Pellagra-like symptoms which are due to deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate. INH inhibits pyridoxal kinase. It is needed to phosphorylate Pyridoxine into pyridoxal 5-P leading to its deficiency in the body. Another concept is INH forms complex with pyridoxine to form hydrazone. It brings about incomplete phosphorylation of pyridoxine. INH inhibits the enzyme pyridoxal kinase, which is necessary for the phosphorylation of pyridoxine. Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation during isoniazid (INH) therapy is necessary for some patients to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy. As Vit. B6 (PLP) is required for Niacin synthesis from tryptophan. Hence Isoniazid therapy also causes Niacin deficiency.
